data.title: Bi-bi-binary numeration
data.statement:
Boby Lapointe created an hexadecimal numeration system in order to shrink the names of the numbers and for fun.
Each 4-bit digit is coded as a syllable, a consonant and a vowel.
The vowel is the lower 2 bits, the consonant is the higher 2 digits.
Lower bits:
`0  1  2  3
[[O]] [[A]] [[E]] [[I]]`
Higher bits:
`0  4  8 12
[[H]] [[B]] [[K]] [[D]]`
So:
0 is [[HO]], 1 is [[HA]], 2 is [[HE]] and 3 is [[HI]].
Then 4 is [[BO]], 8 is [[KO]] and 12 is [[DO]].
So, 5 is [[BA]], 9 is [[KA]] and 13 is [[DA]],
6 is [[BE]], 10 is [[KE]] and 14 is [[DE]],
7 is [[BI]], 11 is [[KI]] and 15 is [[DI]].
16 is [[HAHO]], 17 is [[HAHA]], 18 is [[HAHE]] and so on.
For example, 156 is [[KADO]] because 156=9C in hexadecimal and 9 is [[KA]] and C=12 is [[DO]].
data.constraints: The numbers are below one billion.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Boby Lapointe created an hexadecimal numeration system in order to shrink the names of the numbers and for fun.
Each 4-bit digit is coded as a syllable, a consonant and a vowel.
The vowel is the lower 2 bits, the consonant is the higher 2 digits.
Lower bits:
0  1  2  3
O A E I

Higher bits:
0  4  8 12
H B K D

So:
0 is HO, 1 is HA, 2 is HE and 3 is HI.
Then 4 is BO, 8 is KO and 12 is DO.
So, 5 is BA, 9 is KA and 13 is DA,
6 is BE, 10 is KE and 14 is DE,
7 is BI, 11 is KI and 15 is DI.
16 is HAHO, 17 is HAHA, 18 is HAHE and so on.
For example, 156 is KADO because 156=9C in hexadecimal and 9 is KA and C=12 is DO.
Input
You are given a number.
Output
Print its bi-bi-binary representation.
Constraints
The numbers are below one billion.
Example
Input
0
Output
HO
